Row.Text: This building represents the blessing from a Sacred Peak designated by a Great Person. It provides +2 Culture and +2 Faith to the city.
This building represents an enhanced blessing from a Sacred Peak adjacent to a Sky Burial Ground. It provides +4 Culture and +4 Faith to the city.
Active Chöd Ceremony providing +33% Great Person generation and +50% theming bonus.
Chöd Ceremony near a Mountain providing +50% Tourism from Great Works.

Nyatri Tsenpo, the legendary first king of Tibet, is said to have descended from heaven on a sky-cord, landing on the sacred mountain Yarlha Shampo. According to Tibetan tradition, he was recognized as a divine ruler by the people of the Yarlung Valley, who carried him on their shoulders to establish the first royal dynasty. His reign marks the beginning of recorded Tibetan history and the foundation of the Yarlung Dynasty.

Central to the mythology of early Tibetan kings was the mu-thag or "heavenly cord" - a divine rope that connected the rulers to the celestial realm. It was believed that the first seven kings, including Nyatri Tsenpo, did not die but ascended back to heaven via this cord, leaving no earthly remains. This connection between heaven and earth became fundamental to Tibetan concepts of divine kingship.

Under Nyatri Tsenpo's legendary rule, the foundations of Tibetan culture were established. The Bon religion, with its emphasis on sky burial and mountain worship, flourished. Sacred peaks were venerated as dwelling places of deities, and the practice of sky burial connected the deceased with the heavens. These traditions would endure for millennia, shaping Tibetan spiritual and cultural identity.

Nyatri Tsenpo is credited with building Yumbulakang, considered Tibet's first palace and one of its oldest structures. Perched on a hill in the Yarlung Valley, this fortress-palace served as the seat of the early Tibetan kings. Its strategic location allowed control over the fertile valley below, establishing the pattern of hilltop fortresses that would characterize Tibetan architecture.

Whether historical figure or mythical archetype, Nyatri Tsenpo represents the dawn of Tibetan civilization. His story embodies the unique Tibetan worldview that sees rulers as intermediaries between heaven and earth. The dynasty he founded would eventually unite the Tibetan plateau, creating an empire that at its height rivaled Tang China. His legacy lives on in Tibetan cultural memory as the divine ancestor of all subsequent rulers.
Lord of the Yarlung Valley[NEWLINE]He Who Descended from Heaven

Blessings upon you, Nyatri Tsenpo, first among kings—Tsenpo of the Sky-Cord—who descended upon the Yarlung Valley borne on the shoulders of the people, your feet too sacred to touch the earth. From the cradle of Yarlung you raised the standard of kingship and set the order of heaven upon the land. Your palace at Yumbu Lagang rose like a falcon upon the ridge, a beacon for clans to gather and a seed from which Tibetan civilization would unfurl across the high snows. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] By your divine wisdom, the mountain gods were given their seats and the winds were yoked to banners of the Wind Horse. You bound valley to valley with oath and custom, decreed rites that returned the noble dead to the open sky, and taught that peaks themselves could be sanctuaries where earth receives the blessing of the heavens. Terraces bit into the slopes, watchtowers crowned the passes, and sacred ways climbed toward the sun and moon—each stone a vow that the sky-cord would never be severed. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Now, divine sovereign, your people call upon you once more. Will you designate new sacred peaks to channel the favor of the heavens? Will you raise palaces and sanctuaries from Yarlung to the world’s edge? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time?
I am Nyatri Tsenpo, descended from heaven to rule these lands. The sacred peaks bear witness to our meeting.
The heavenly cord is severed... but the mountains remember, and one day another shall descend.
Even friends must honor the sacred cord. Betrayal will not be forgotten by the mountains.
You attack the descendant of heaven? The peaks will shield me, and your aggression will echo in the valleys.
War is a test of destiny.
Your expansion encroaches upon lands blessed by heaven. Respect the boundaries, or face the wrath of heaven.
Your intentions are clouded. The sky watches those who bring discord.
We meet as equals beneath the sky. Let us see what fate has in store.
Greetings. May our words be as clear as the mountain air.
Your armies stir the valleys. Beware, for the peaks stand ready to defend their own.
Let us trade the blessings of our lands. Prosperity is best when shared.
Open borders may unite our peoples, but respect must guide your steps.
Do not claim land sacred to my ancestors. The harmony between heaven and earth must remain unbroken.
Denounce me if you must, but the mountains endure beyond words.
Friendship takes time, as does the shaping of mountains. Let us build trust first.
Peace cannot be rushed. The fate will reveal its path in time.
Your actions dishonor yourself. I denounce you before the spirits of the mountains.
Let us walk together beneath the sky, as friends joined by destiny should.
The Cord Uniting Heaven and Earth

When a Great Person is born, designate the nearest Mountain as a Sacred Peak for 25 turns (max 3). Each Sacred Peak grants its nearest city +2[ICON_CULTURE]Culture and +2[ICON_PEACE]Faith (doubled if a Sky Burial Ground is adjacent). When that Great Person is expended, transfer the Sacred Peak to the expending city's nearest Mountain and refresh its duration.

Unique Great Musician replacement. Can perform a Chöd Ceremony: one-time ability that expends the Pawo in a city. For 10 turns, that city gains +33%[ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person Rate per Great Work it contains and +50% theming bonus. If the city is within 2 tiles of a Mountain, gain +50%[ICON_TOURISM]Tourism from Great Works for the duration.

The Pawo is a unique Great Musician replacement for Yarlung. Instead of a concert tour, the Pawo can perform a Chöd Ceremony in a city, providing powerful cultural bonuses for 10 turns. The ceremony is especially effective in cities near mountains. Use Pawos to boost your cultural victory by enhancing cities with multiple Great Works and theming bonuses.

Pawos are heroic dancers and mediums in the Tibetan spiritual tradition. Through elaborate costumes and ritualistic performances, they conduct the Chöd ceremony - a practice of offering one's body to demons and spirits to cultivate compassion and overcome ego. These spiritual warriors dance at the boundary between the physical and spiritual worlds, channeling divine energies to benefit all sentient beings.

Must be built adjacent to a Mountain and cannot be adjacent to another Sky Burial Ground. Yields +2[ICON_CULTURE]Culture and +2[ICON_PEACE]Faith, plus +1 of each for every adjacent Mountain and Great Person Improvement. Yields +1[ICON_TOURISM]Tourism after researching Archaeology.

Sky burial grounds are sacred sites where the deceased are offered to vultures and the elements, returning the body to nature and sending the spirit skyward. These charnel grounds serve as powerful reminders of impermanence and the cycle of life and death. Located near mountains - the abodes of gods and spirits - they represent the intersection of earth and heaven, making them places of profound spiritual significance in Tibetan culture.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Sacred Peak Designated![ENDCOLOR] {1_GPName} has blessed a mountain near {2_CityName}!
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Sacred Peak Transferred![ENDCOLOR] The blessing has moved to a mountain near {1_CityName}!
A Sacred Peak's blessing has expired.
Maximum Sacred Peaks reached! A Great Person must be expended to designate a new one.
No mountain found nearby to designate as Sacred Peak!
Sacred Peak lost - no mountain near the expenditure location!
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Chöd Ceremony![ENDCOLOR] Performed in {1_CityName}! Great Person rates and tourism boosted for {2_Turns} turns.
Sky Burial Ground built with +{1_Culture}[ICON_CULTURE]Culture and +{2_Faith}[ICON_PEACE]Faith from adjacency!
